title: Compute Leaf (Backup)
summary: This community centers around COMPUTE_LEAF_02, identified as a backup Top-of-Rack (ToR) switch dedicated to compute resources. It features an uplink to a spine network (10.0.2.2/30) with a 9000 MTU, indicating support for jumbo frames. Downlink connectivity for compute servers is provided via a bond (bond_tor_compute) operating in 802.3ad LACP mode, which includes eth_downlink_srv8. A VLAN interface (vlan20_vm, VLAN ID 20) is configured on this bond, serving as the gateway (172.16.20.254/24) for virtual machines.
rating_explanation: As a backup ToR switch for compute, its failure would impact redundancy and potentially lead to service disruption if the primary compute leaf is also down or overloaded. It handles VM traffic, which is often critical for application hosting.
findings: Device COMPUTE_LEAF_02 is a backup ToR switch for compute resources.
Uplink eth_uplink_spine1 uses IP 10.0.2.2/30 and supports Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000).
Downlink bond_tor_compute uses 802.3ad LACP for redundancy and load balancing.
VLAN 20 (vlan20_vm) is configured for VM traffic with gateway 172.16.20.254/24.

The bond 'bond_tor_compute' is configured with 802.3ad, but only one member interface ('eth_downlink_srv8') is explicitly listed in the provided data, which could indicate a single physical link or incomplete data.

title: Primary Storage Leaf
summary: This community describes STORAGE_LEAF_01, the primary Top-of-Rack (ToR) switch for storage infrastructure. It connects to a spine network via eth_uplink_spine1 (10.0.3.2/30) and supports Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000). Downlink connectivity to storage servers is managed by bond_tor_storage, an 802.3ad LACP bond that includes eth_downlink_srv7. A dedicated VLAN (vlan30_san, VLAN ID 30) for SAN traffic is configured on this bond, acting as the gateway (172.16.30.253/24) for storage devices. All relevant interfaces and the VLAN also support MTU 9000, optimizing for high-throughput storage traffic.
rating_explanation: This is the primary ToR switch for storage, handling critical SAN traffic. Its availability is paramount for data access and application performance. Any disruption would severely impact storage services across the infrastructure.
findings: Device STORAGE_LEAF_01 is the primary ToR switch for storage.
Uplink eth_uplink_spine1 uses IP 10.0.3.2/30 and supports Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000).
Downlink bond_tor_storage uses 802.3ad LACP for redundancy and load balancing.
VLAN 30 (vlan30_san) is configured for SAN traffic with gateway 172.16.30.253/24.
End-to-end Jumbo Frame support (MTU 9000) is configured on uplink, downlink, and SAN VLAN, which is optimal for storage traffic.

The bond 'bond_tor_storage' is configured with 802.3ad, but only one member interface ('eth_downlink_srv7') is explicitly listed in the provided data, which could indicate a single physical link or incomplete data.

title: Backup Storage Leaf
summary: This community details STORAGE_LEAF_02, designated as the backup Top-of-Rack (ToR) switch for storage. It provides an uplink to a spine network (eth_uplink_spine2, 10.0.13.2/30) with Jumbo Frame support (MTU 9000). Similar to its primary counterpart, it uses bond_tor_storage (an 802.3ad LACP bond including eth_downlink_srv7) for downlink connectivity to storage servers. VLAN 30 (vlan30_san) is configured on this bond, serving as the backup gateway (172.16.30.254/24) for SAN traffic. All critical interfaces and the SAN VLAN are configured with MTU 9000.
rating_explanation: As a backup ToR switch for storage, it provides crucial redundancy for SAN traffic. While not the primary, its failure would compromise the high availability of storage services, making it highly important for business continuity.
findings: Device STORAGE_LEAF_02 is a backup ToR switch for storage.
Uplink eth_uplink_spine2 uses IP 10.0.13.2/30 and supports Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000).
Downlink bond_tor_storage uses 802.3ad LACP for redundancy and load balancing.
VLAN 30 (vlan30_san) is configured for SAN traffic with gateway 172.16.30.254/24.
End-to-end Jumbo Frame support (MTU 9000) is configured on uplink, downlink, and SAN VLAN.

The bond 'bond_tor_storage' is configured with 802.3ad, but only one member interface ('eth_downlink_srv7') is explicitly listed in the provided data, which could indicate a single physical link or incomplete data.

title: High-Performance Storage Server
summary: This community describes a HIGH_PERFORMANCE_STORAGE_SERVER, identified as a NAS/SAN target. It features dual physical interfaces (eno1, eno2) configured with Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000), which are aggregated into bond0_storage. This bond operates in 802.3ad LACP mode with a layer3+4 hash policy, ensuring both redundancy and efficient load balancing for storage traffic. A VLAN interface (bond0.30, VLAN ID 30) is configured on this bond, providing the server's SAN IP address (172.16.30.10/24) and routing traffic for the 172.16.30.0/24 subnet via 172.16.30.253 (which corresponds to STORAGE_LEAF_01). All network components on the server are configured for MTU 9000, optimizing for high-throughput storage operations.
rating_explanation: This is a critical storage server (NAS/SAN target) that likely hosts vital data and applications. Its availability and performance are paramount for the entire infrastructure. Any issues with this server would have a severe impact on data access and business operations.
findings: Device HIGH_PERFORMANCE_STORAGE_SERVER is a critical NAS/SAN target.
Dual physical interfaces (eno1, eno2) are bonded using 802.3ad LACP with layer3+4 hash policy for high availability and performance.
End-to-end Jumbo Frame support (MTU 9000) is configured on physical interfaces, bond, and SAN VLAN.
The server connects to VLAN 30 (SAN) with IP 172.16.30.10/24.

The server's route for the 172.16.30.0/24 subnet is via 172.16.30.253, indicating STORAGE_LEAF_01 as its primary gateway for SAN traffic. This configuration should be reviewed for potential active-active or VRRP/HSRP setup with STORAGE_LEAF_02 (172.16.30.254) to ensure full gateway redundancy for the storage server.

title: Compute Hypervisor Network Stack
summary: This community details the network configuration of a single compute hypervisor. It utilizes a robust network setup featuring a Link Aggregation Group (LAG) `bond0_compute` (802.3ad LACP) composed of `eth0` and `eth1` for redundancy and increased throughput. Two VLANs, `bond0.10` and `bond0.20`, are configured over this bond. VLAN 10 is assigned an IP address (`192.168.1.100/24`) and gateway, likely for management or host services. VLAN 20 is dedicated to virtual machine data traffic, bridged to `br_vm_data` where Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) is disabled and forward-delay is zero, a common optimization for hypervisor internal bridges.
rating_explanation: A compute hypervisor is a foundational component for virtualized services. Its network configuration is critical for the availability, performance, and isolation of all hosted virtual machines. A failure or misconfiguration in this network stack would directly impact multiple services. The use of bonding provides resilience, but it remains a single point of failure at the host level.
findings: Single compute hypervisor with a redundant LACP bond (`bond0_compute`) for physical interface resilience.
Network segmentation implemented using VLANs (10 and 20) over the bonded interface.
VLAN 10 is configured with an IP address and gateway, suggesting a management or service network.
VLAN 20 is dedicated to VM data traffic, connected to a bridge (`br_vm_data`).
STP is disabled on `br_vm_data` with zero forward-delay, typical for hypervisor internal bridging.

title: Dual Redundant Edge Routers
summary: This community describes a pair of edge routers, `EDGE_ROUTER_01` (primary) and `EDGE_ROUTER_02` (secondary), providing redundant WAN connectivity. Both routers connect to the internet via the same gateway (`203.0.113.1`) but use distinct public IP addresses (`203.0.113.10/24` and `203.0.113.11/24`). Internally, they establish separate point-to-point links (`/30` subnets) to different spine routers (`lan0_to_spine1` and `lan0_to_spine2`). Each edge router has a static route to the `172.16.0.0/16` internal network via its respective spine connection, ensuring reachability to the core.
rating_explanation: These edge routers are the critical ingress/egress points for all external network traffic, including internet access. Their proper functioning is paramount for business operations. While redundancy is built-in with two devices, a failure in both or a misconfiguration could lead to a complete loss of external connectivity and impact internal routing to core networks.
findings: Two distinct edge routers provide redundant WAN connectivity and internal routing.
Both routers share a common external gateway but have unique public IP addresses.
Dedicated internal links (`/30` subnets) connect each edge router to a different spine router.
Static routes are configured on both edge routers to direct traffic for `172.16.0.0/16` towards their respective spine connections.

title: Spine Router 1 (Core L3)
summary: This community focuses on `SPINE_ROUTER_01`, a high-performance Layer 3 core router. It features multiple interfaces configured with a large MTU of 9000 bytes, indicating support for jumbo frames, essential for high-throughput data center environments. It establishes point-to-point `/30` links to several leaf devices (`eth_to_leaf3`, `eth_to_leaf4`, `eth_to_leaf5`) and connects to an edge router (`eth_to_edge9`) via a `10.200.1.2/30` link. The router is configured with equal-cost static routes to `172.16.20.0/24` and `172.16.30.0/24` via its leaf connections, suggesting an Equal-Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) routing strategy for load balancing and redundancy to downstream networks.
rating_explanation: As a core Layer 3 router, `SPINE_ROUTER_01` is a central hub for internal network traffic, connecting edge routers to leaf switches and facilitating inter-VLAN routing. Its performance and availability are crucial for the entire network's operation. A failure would significantly disrupt internal communication and potentially isolate large segments of the network.
findings: `SPINE_ROUTER_01` functions as a core Layer 3 router, central to the network fabric.
Interfaces are configured with MTU 9000, enabling jumbo frame support for high-performance traffic.
Establishes point-to-point links to multiple leaf switches and an edge router.
Implements Equal-Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) routing for `172.16.20.0/24` and `172.16.30.0/24` via different leaf connections, enhancing load balancing and redundancy.

title: Spine Router 2 (Redundant Core L3)
summary: This community describes `SPINE_ROUTER_02`, designated as a "Redundant L3 Core" router, complementing `SPINE_ROUTER_01`. It also features interfaces configured with MTU 9000 for jumbo frame support. It connects to leaf devices (`eth_to_leaf3`, `eth_to_leaf6`) via `/30` point-to-point links and to an edge router (`eth_to_edge10`) via a `10.200.2.2/30` link. The explicit "Redundant L3 Core" role highlights its importance in providing high availability and load balancing for the core network, working in tandem with other spine routers.
rating_explanation: As a redundant core Layer 3 router, `SPINE_ROUTER_02` is equally vital to the network's resilience and performance as `SPINE_ROUTER_01`. It ensures continued operation and load distribution in case of a failure in other core components. Its failure would compromise the network's redundancy, potentially leading to performance degradation or outages if the primary spine is also affected.
findings: `SPINE_ROUTER_02` serves as a redundant core Layer 3 router, enhancing network resilience.
Interfaces are configured with MTU 9000, supporting jumbo frames.
Establishes point-to-point links to leaf switches and an edge router.

The connection to `eth_to_leaf3` on `SPINE_ROUTER_02` uses a different subnet (`10.0.11.1/30`) than `eth_to_leaf3` on `SPINE_ROUTER_01` (`10.0.1.1/30`), suggesting `leaf3` has dual uplinks to both spines.
Explicitly identified as a "Redundant L3 Core," confirming its role in a highly available network design.
